channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hurricane Ian Leaves Behind a Staggering Scale of Damage in Florida
item.description: The extent of the damage was difficult to comprehend, even for residents who had survived and rebuilt after other powerful storms.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Frances Robles and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Jayme Gershen and Orlando Castro for The New York Times

item.title: Putin Plans Annexation of Ukraine Territories. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: The Kremlin is using pageantry and a show of adhering to Russian legal formalities to give the move a veneer of legitimacy.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A local resident rides past an abandoned Russian tank in Kramatorsk, eastern Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: Ukraine Says 25 People Died in Attack on Civilians in Zaporizhzhia
item.description: People in the convoy were waiting to be allowed into Russian-occupied territory to pick up relatives and deliver humanitarian aid, a Ukrainian official said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:description: A Ukrainian serviceman covering a body of a civilian killed by a missile strike near Zaporizhzhia on Friday.

item.title: Eurozone Inflation Sets Another Record, Hitting 10 Percent in September
item.description: Jumps in energy and food prices again pushed inflation in the 19 countries that use the euro to the highest annual rate recorded since the currency was created.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen and Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: A fruit vendor in Athens. Food prices in the eurozone rose nearly 12 percent in the year through September.

item.title: New Inflation Data Shows Prices Remain Stubbornly High
item.description: Inflation remains far above the Federal Reserve’s goal, and prices climbed more quickly than economists expected in August.
item.dc:creator: Jeanna Smialek
item.media:credit: Mark Abramson for The New York Times
item.media:description: A shopping center in Los Angeles this month. Consumers continued to spend in August, the Commerce Department reported.

item.title: Bonds May Be Having Their Worst Year Yet
item.description: This has been the most devastating time for bonds since at least 1926, and maybe in centuries. But, our columnist writes, much of the damage is already behind us.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Sommer

item.title: Confused by the New Mortgage Gimmicks? Here’s a Guide.
item.description: Mortgage lenders are offering incentives to borrowers, hoping to lure them even as rates soar. It’s up to consumers to sort it all out.
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard
item.category: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp (Freddie Mac)

item.title: Even as Iranians Rise Up, Protests Worldwide Are Failing at Record Rates
item.description: Mass protests, once a grave threat to even the fiercest autocrat, have plummeted in effectiveness, a study shows. Factors appear to include polarization, social media and rising nationalist attitudes.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.media:description: Iranian demonstrators in the streets of the capital, Tehran, last week. Protests erupted around the country after the death of a young woman, Mahsa Amini, following her detainment in police custody.

item.title: Early Cormac McCarthy Interviews Rediscovered
item.description: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author has done vanishingly few interviews during the course of his career. In these early ones, some newly uncovered, he is less guarded.
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth A. Harris
item.media:description: Cormac McCarthy at his writing desk in Blount County, Tenn., as printed in the Maryville-Alcoa Times on Feb. 26, 1971.

item.title: Judge Overrules Special Master’s Demands to Trump in Document Review
item.description: The dueling moves by Judge Aileen M. Cannon and a special master she appointed reflected a larger struggle over who should control the rules of the review — and whom those rules would favor.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Alan Feuer
item.media:description: Lawyers for former President Donald J. Trump had objected to several of the special master’s requirements.

item.title: Ginni Thomas Repeats False 2020 Election Claim in Jan. 6 Interview
item.description: In a closed-door interview with the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack, Ms. Thomas reiterated her false assertion that the 2020 election was stolen from President Donald J. Trump.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater and Stephanie Lai
item.category: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack
item.media:description: Ginni Thomas, the wife of Clarence Thomas.

item.title: A Year Under the Taliban
item.description: A single year of extremist rule has turned life upside down for Afghans, especially women. A photographer who has long called the country home captured the jarring changes.
item.dc:creator: Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: Blast at Education Center in Kabul Kills at Least 19
item.description: The violence was the latest to target the country’s Hazara ethnic minority and increased fears about the Taliban’s ability to provide security for all of their citizens.
item.dc:creator: Yaqoob Akbary and Christina Goldbaum
item.media:description: Relatives and medical staff tending to one of the victims of an attack on a learning center Friday in the Dasht-e-Barchi neighborhood in Kabul.

item.title: Trevor Noah Will Leave ‘The Daily Show’
item.description: During a taping of the Comedy Central program Thursday night, he noted that it has been seven years since he replaced Jon Stewart. He will depart at a time to be determined, he said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.category: The Daily Show with Trevor Noah (TV Program)
item.media:description: Trevor Noah was a 31-year-old South African comic not yet well known in the United States when he became the host of one of the crown jewels of the Comedy Central lineup.

item.title: ‘Anne Rice’s Interview With the Vampire’: Old Monsters, New Blood
item.description: AMC has a lot riding on the series, which makes major changes to the original story. Will the millions of Rice fans sink their teeth into it?
item.dc:creator: Erik Piepenburg
item.media:credit: Clement Pascal for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jacob Anderson, left, and Sam Reid play Louis and Lestat in “Anne Rice’s Interview With the Vampire” in which their characters share a more overtly sexual bond than in the book.

item.title: Living With Grandparents: Cross-Generational Homes Bring Families Together
item.description: More young adults are moving in with their grandparents, in a trend known as “skipped-generation” households.
item.dc:creator: Joanne Kaufman
item.media:credit: Clark Hodgin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Robert E. Elson had to grow use to having his granddaughter, Madeline David, as a roommate. “Amazingly, no head-butting,” Mr. Elson said.

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol

item.title: If Bolsonaro Loses Brazil’s Election, Will He Respect the Result?
item.description: Brazilians are holding our breath.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Barbara
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A man in a shirt with the image of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who is seeking to regain Brazil’s presidency, in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday

item.title: Ethereum’s Founder on What Crypto Can — and Can’t — Do
item.description: Vitalik Buterin explains digital currency’s potential to transform our world.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Ezra Klein Show’

item.title: The Crisis of Men and Boys
item.description: Men have opportunities, but they’re not taking them.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.category: Of Boys and Men: Why the Modern Male Is Struggling, Why It Matters, and What to Do about It (Book)

item.title: Why China’s Crimes in Xinjiang Cannot Go Unpunished
item.description: China is dragging the world back to a human rights dark age. It’s time to push back.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Bequelin
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Is the Fed Braking Too Hard?
item.description: It may be raising interest rates too far, too fast.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: Donald Can’t Quit Maggie
item.description: A Times reporter’s new biography of Trump shows the boundlessness of his self-regard.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.category: Confidence Man: The Making of Donald Trump and the Breaking of America (Book)

item.title: Gerrymandering, the Full Story
item.description: A Times analysis finds that the House of Representative has its fairest map in 40 years, despite recent gerrymandering.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Congressional gerrymandering is a smaller problem than it has been for much of the recent past.

item.title: Florida After Hurricane Ian
item.description: Times reporters on the ground take stock of one of the deadliest storms ever to hit the state.
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Nina Feldman, Sydney Harper, Eric Krupke, Jessica Cheung, Rachel Quester, Luke Vander Ploeg, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Fort Myers Beach, Fla., yesterday. About 700 Floridians have been rescued from floodwater, and 2.4 million residents were without power.

item.title: Dreaming of Spaghetti and (Meatless) Meatballs
item.description: Ricotta polpette, vegetarian Swedish meatballs and plant-based meatballs.
item.dc:creator: Tejal Rao
item.media:credit: David Malosh for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Barrett Washburne.

item.title: New Europa Pictures Beamed Home by NASA’s Juno Spacecraft
item.description: The space probe has been studying Jupiter since 2016 and just flew within about 200 miles of the surface of the ice-covered ocean moon.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: A detail of an image captured by NASA's Juno spacecraft during a flyby on Thursday shows the complex, ice-covered surface of Jupiter's moon Europa.

item.title: F.D.A. Moves to Change ‘Healthy’ Food Definition
item.description: Salmon is in; sugary yogurt is out.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Sara Hylton for The New York Times

item.title: Bill Plante, CBS News’s Man at the White House, Dies at 84
item.description: He covered four presidencies in a 52-year career and never worried about “offending those in power in pursuit of answers,” one former White House press secretary said.
item.dc:creator: Richard Sandomir

item.title: Shakira Is Accused of Tax Evasion in Spain. Here’s What We Know.
item.description: Prosecutors have charged the Colombian singer and pop star with six counts of tax fraud for failing to pay 14.5 million euros in income taxes. She could face a steep fine and a prison sentence.
item.dc:creator: Remy Tumin and José Bautista
item.media:description: Shakira arriving for the screening of “Elvis” during the Cannes Film Festival in May. She has been wrapped in a tax evasion case in Spain.

item.title: Dense Breasts and Cancer: What to Know About Katie Couric’s Diagnosis
item.description: Katie Couric, who revealed on Wednesday that she had breast cancer, also said she had dense breasts. Here’s what that means and how it might influence cancer risk.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum
item.media:credit: Torin Halsey/Times Record News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: You should get a mammogram each year starting at age 40 and ask your doctor if you have dense breasts.

item.title: Covid Vaccines Temporarily Affect Periods, New Study Shows
item.description: Experts say there is no indication that vaccines affect fertility. Most people’s periods go back to normal within one cycle.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times

item.title: Do Antidepressants Really Work?
item.description: While the drugs are widely used, a new study sheds light on how little is known about their long-term benefits.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by Getty Images

item.title: What Your Dog’s Behavior Means
item.description: Dogs are “really good at reading our emotions,” says one expert. But we’re not so good at reading theirs.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Illustration by Nicolas Ortega; Photograph by Getty Images

item.title: Can You Get Addicted to Melatonin?
item.description: The sleep supplement doesn’t cause physical dependence, but falling asleep without it can be tricky for some people.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: ‘Hocus Pocus 2’ Review: Still Spelling Trouble
item.description: The Sanderson sisters return, bringing the same spooky humor with some modern twists.
item.dc:creator: Claire Shaffer

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
